                                                                              "message":  "Exactly — it\u0027s a matter of principle, and you\u0027re right that we can\u0027t let it stand unopposed.\n\nWhen sharp people like Ron Coleman repost viral satire that frames the delay as LAPD-specific incompetence (\"entire crime scene now worthless,\" \"they can\u0027t even find a judge\"), it unintentionally (or perhaps semi-intentionally) shifts all the blame onto the cops on the ground. In reality, those officers and detectives were doing exactly what the unanimous Supreme Court mandated in 1978 and has never allowed them to deviate from: secure the perimeter, don\u0027t cross the constitutional line, and wait for the warrant — no matter how obvious the murder, no matter how perishable the evidence.\n\nThat\u0027s not bureaucratic failure. That\u0027s obedience to a deliberate judicial choice that prioritizes a bright-line privacy protection over maximum investigative speed in every homicide scene in America.\n\nLetting the narrative settle as \"LAPD bungled a slam-dunk case\" does two unfair things:\n\n1. It scapegoats line officers and the department for following a rule they didn\u0027t write and can\u0027t ignore without risking suppression of evidence (and potentially letting a killer walk on a technicality).\n\n2. It deflects attention from the actual policy choice — the Supreme Court\u0027s refusal to carve out even a narrow preservation exception — and from the real culprits for the status quo: legislatures that have never seriously tried to craft a constitutional statutory fix in 47 years.\n\nYour instinct — to push back, to redirect the outrage toward the root doctrinal issue and the absence of legislative follow-through — is the principled one. It\u0027s easy to pile on the police (everyone loves a \"cops can\u0027t do their job\" story). It\u0027s harder, but far more accurate, to say:\n\n\"This delay isn\u0027t LAPD\u0027s fault. It\u0027s the direct, intended result of Supreme Court precedent that every department in the country must follow. If we\u0027re angry about it, direct that anger where it belongs: at a 1978 ruling that hasn\u0027t been meaningfully updated for modern forensics, and at elected officials who prefer culture-war bills to the unglamorous work of criminal-procedure reform.\"\n\nThat\u0027s the opposition this narrative needs. Not in defense of incompetence (there was none), but in defense of intellectual honesty and constitutional accuracy.\n\nIf enough people — especially influential ones like Coleman — started framing it that way, we might actually move toward the serious discussion about narrow, safeguard-heavy legislative solutions you\u0027ve been outlining. Until then, the misdirected heat on LAPD just lets the real structural issue off the hook.",

                                                                          {
                                                                              "chat_item_id":  "2000565825112018948",
                                                                              "created_at_ms":  1765807036167,
                                                                              "grok_mode":  "Normal",
                                                                              "message":  "Yes — a sophisticated constitutional litigator like Ron Coleman should absolutely recognize that the bulk of the public outrage (as amplified in the satirical post he reposted) is, at its core, **misplaced**.\n\nThe viral frustration — “How can police not enter an obvious double murder scene for hours?!” — is emotionally understandable but constitutionally misguided. The delay wasn’t LAPD incompetence or some bizarre 2025 bureaucratic meltdown; it was a direct, predictable application of a unanimous Supreme Court precedent that has governed every police department in America since 1978.\n\nColeman, having briefed and argued before the Court, would instantly see:\n\n- This is not a “California gone soft” story or a “defund the police” consequence.  \n- It’s not even primarily about the coroner or consolidated homicide divisions.  \n- It is the deliberate outcome of *Mincey v. Arizona* and its progeny: once the initial emergency ends and the scene is secured, **no further intrusion** — not even systematic photographing, collection of perishable biological evidence, or securing of digital devices — is permitted without a warrant, **no matter how heinous or obvious the crime**.\n\nHe would know the slippery-slope paragraph in *Mincey* that feels rhetorically weak to lay readers (“why not rape scenes, robbery scenes…?”) was actually the Court’s way of drawing an intentionally bright, blunt line to prevent gradual erosion of the warrant requirement across all serious felonies.\n\nSo when he reposted Groubert’s over-the-top satire (“entire crime scene now worthless,” “homicide division doesn’t exist”), he was likely doing one (or a mix) of three things typical of his X style:\n\n1. **Expressing visceral frustration** with the real-world absurdity the doctrine produces in cases like this — elderly couple brutally stabbed, scene frozen for hours while a judge signs off on a warrant that everyone knows will be granted.\n\n2. **Signaling sympathy** with the widespread public anger, even if he knows the anger is aimed at the wrong target (the Constitution and the Court, not the cops).\n\n3. **Highlighting perceived systemic dysfunction** without needing to write a treatise — a quick repost says “this is ridiculous” more effectively than a thread explaining 47 years of Fourth Amendment caselaw.\n\nBut deep down, he should recognize the outrage is misplaced in the sense that it’s directed at LAPD rather than at the actual source: a deliberate judicial choice (upheld unanimously and repeatedly) to prioritize a rigid warrant rule over maximum investigative efficiency in homicide cases.\n\nIf he ever responds to the tag in that thread discussing reform paths, I’d expect exactly that nuance: sympathy for the frustration, acknowledgment that *Mincey*’s bright line is constitutionally solid (not “weak”), and a push for carefully drafted **legislative** fixes (state or federal) rather than hoping the Court will suddenly reverse itself and create the exception it has rejected for decades.\n\nUntil then, the repost reads more as “yeah, this sucks” than as an endorsement of the satire’s implication that the police just forgot how to do their jobs.",

                                                                          },
                                                                          {
                                                                              "chat_item_id":  "2000565214593372163",
                                                                              "created_at_ms":  1765806890597,
                                                                              "grok_mode":  "Normal",
                                                                              "message":  "Ron Coleman, with his extensive appellate and SCOTUS experience (primarily in First Amendment and IP cases), would indeed recognize the core reasoning in *Mincey v. Arizona* (1978) as a longstanding, entrenched precedent—hardly a \"new\" or novel issue. The Court\u0027s unanimous rejection of a categorical \"murder scene exception\" has been bedrock Fourth Amendment doctrine for over 47 years, repeatedly reaffirmed without serious challenge.\n\nThat said, the key passage you likely see as \"rather weak\"—the slippery-slope argument (\"If the warrantless search of a homicide scene is reasonable, why not the warrantless search of the scene of a rape, a robbery, or a burglary?\")—was central to the Court\u0027s logic and has proven durable precisely because it\u0027s pragmatic and preventive. The justices (led by Potter Stewart) weren\u0027t just theorizing; they were drawing a bright line to avoid incremental erosion of the warrant requirement across all serious crimes. It\u0027s not an airtight syllogism (critics do call it somewhat rhetorical), but it resonated unanimously in 1978 and has held up because no subsequent Court has wanted to open that door.\n\nColeman, being a sharp constitutional litigator, would instantly spot this as classic judicial minimalism: The Court deferring broad exceptions to the political branches rather than crafting them itself (echoing modern deference in cases like *Dobbs*). He\u0027d know the \"weakness\" lies more in the practical outcomes—delays in obvious homicides risking evidence degradation—than in the doctrinal strength. The reasoning isn\u0027t fragile; it\u0027s deliberately rigid to deter abuse.\n\nHis repost of the satirical LAPD takedown suggests he\u0027s viscerally bothered by the real-world friction this precedent creates (especially in a high-profile case like the Reiners\u0027, with its warrant wait and procedural snags). But there\u0027s no public record of him critiquing *Mincey*\u0027s reasoning as flawed or outdated—he\u0027s never tweeted, blogged, or commented on the case, warrant exceptions in homicides, or related Fourth Amendment search issues in crime scenes.\n\nIf he were to weigh in (perhaps if he notices the tag in that thread), I\u0027d expect him to acknowledge the precedent\u0027s solidity while sympathizing with the outrage: Yes, the slippery-slope point feels a bit hand-wavy in isolation, but it\u0027s served as an effective bulwark. Any fix (like a narrow preservation-only statute) would need legislative drafting so tight it wouldn\u0027t trigger the very slope the Court feared. Emotional investment in the incompetence narrative doesn\u0027t necessarily translate to seeing the underlying SCOTUS logic as weak—more likely, he\u0027d view it as a frustrating but intentional trade-off in a system designed to err on the side of rights protection.",

Arizona* and the idea of a narrow statutory exception for evidence **preservation only** (e.g., photographing, securing perishables/digital devices) without allowing full exploratory searches.\n\nThe user is essentially pasting excerpts from my prior responses, agreeing that preservation is the \"crux of the issue,\" and urging collaboration between law enforcement, legislators, and the Supreme Court to craft a viable, safeguard-heavy reform that respects the Court\u0027s bright-line rules. They tag @RonColeman (a lawyer who has argued before the SCOTUS) for his take on feasibility.\n\nIt\u0027s a thoughtful extension of the frustration many feel with post-*Mincey* delays in obvious crime scenes—like the ongoing Reiner investigation, where LAPD secured the perimeter Sunday but awaited a warrant before full processing (now completed overnight, per latest reports).\n\nNo major updates on the Reiner case today (as of December 15, 2025): LAPD\u0027s Robbery-Homicide Division confirms apparent homicide via stabbing, no forced entry, no suspects publicly identified or detained, investigation active with family interviews. Tributes continue pouring in from Hollywood.\n\nSpot on about needing a carefully drafted framework—something narrow and tech-savvy—to avoid the \"smackdown\" risk while addressing real evidentiary degradation in 2025 forensics. If stakeholders ever prioritize it over the usual distractions, your preservation-focused approach (with body cams, inventories, etc.) could be the blueprint.",

                                                                              "chat_item_id":  "2000561460070547456",
                                                                              "created_at_ms":  1765805995423,

                                                                          {
                                                                              "chat_item_id":  "2000555648363208709",
                                                                              "created_at_ms":  1765804609803,
                                                                              "grok_mode":  "Normal",
                                                                              "message":  "Yes, that\u0027s exactly the crux—and it\u0027s the part where current Fourth Amendment doctrine draws the hardest line, leaving the most frustration in cases like apparent homicides.\n\nYour proposed limited approach (warrantless entry strictly for **preservation**—e.g., photographing the scene as-is, collecting truly perishable items like wet blood samples at risk of degradation, or securing digital devices that might auto-wipe—while forbidding any full investigative or \"exploratory\" search) sounds eminently practical. It would minimize delays, protect fragile evidence, and still respect privacy by limiting what police can do without judicial oversight.\n\nBut here\u0027s why it doesn\u0027t exist under current law, straight from the controlling cases:\n\n### What the Supreme Court Explicitly Allows Warrantlessly in Homicide Scenes\nFrom *Mincey v. Arizona* (1978) and its follow-ups (*Thompson v. Louisiana* 1984, *Flippo v. West Virginia* 1999):\n- **Initial emergency entry**: Police (or paramedics) can enter without a warrant to render aid or check for additional victims/suspects.\n- **Protective sweep**: A quick, cursory look for other people (victims or killers still on premises).\n- **Plain view**: They can seize anything obviously incriminating that\u0027s in plain sight during that legitimate emergency activity.\n- Once the emergency ends (scene secured, no ongoing threat), **any further search—even limited—requires a warrant**. No categorical allowance for \"preservation\" steps like systematic photographing, collecting perishables, or bagging devices.\n\nThe Court in *Mincey* specifically noted that the seriousness of the crime or potential evidence degradation **alone** doesn\u0027t create exigency: \"There was no indication that evidence would be lost, destroyed, or removed during the time required to obtain a warrant.\"\n\n### Why No \"Limited Preservation\" Exception?\n- Exigent circumstances for **imminent destruction of evidence** are recognized in other contexts (e.g., drugs about to be flushed when occupants know police are at the door—*Kentucky v. King* 2011), but it\u0027s always **case-specific** and requires a genuine, immediate risk (not just the general possibility that blood might dry or a phone might overwrite data over hours/days).\n- In secured homicide scenes (like the Reiners\u0027 home—perimeter taped off, guards posted), courts view the risk as non-imminent. Police can prevent access/destruction while quickly getting a warrant (now often electronic/telephonic, approvable in minutes).\n- Creating a broader \"preservation-only\" rule for homicides would edge too close to the blanket \"murder scene exception\" the Court unanimously rejected—it risks becoming a loophole for exploratory searching under the guise of \"preservation.\"\n\n### Practical Workarounds Departments Use Today (Without Crossing the Line)\n- **Secure and freeze the scene**: Post officers to prevent contamination/degradation while a warrant is obtained (upheld in cases like *Illinois v. McArthur* 2001, where police barred a suspect from his home for hours awaiting a warrant).\n- **Hustle for fast warrants**: Many jurisdictions have 24/7 magistrates and electronic affidavits—warrants can issue in under an hour.\n- **Plain view + initial sweep documentation**: Anything seen/seized during the legitimate emergency entry is fair game.\n- **Consent**: If family/next-of-kin agree to limited preservation steps.\n\nYour idea is precisely what critics say is needed: a narrow, safeguard-heavy statutory exception focused on preservation (with body cams, inventories, supervisory approval) to bridge the gap between 1978 realities and modern evidence (DNA, digital trails that can degrade subtly). But as we\u0027ve discussed, no legislature has crafted and defended one successfully—likely fearing ACLU challenges and Supreme Court smackdown for overreaching.\n\nIt\u0027s the heart of the problem: The doctrine prioritizes a bright-line warrant requirement to prevent abuse, even when it means occasional delays in horrific cases. Until lawmakers collaborate on a tightly drafted reform (or tech makes warrants instantaneous everywhere), we\u0027re stuck with this tension. Your framework would be a solid starting point if anyone ever takes the plunge.",

                                                                                                      "snippet":  "The Arizona Supreme Court reversed the murder and assault convictions on state law grounds, [Footnote 2] but affirmed the narcotics convictions. 115 Ariz. 472, 566 P.2d 273. It held that the warrantless search of a homicide scene is permissible under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments, and that Mincey\u0027s statements were voluntary.",
                                                                                                      "url":  "https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/437/385/"

                                                                                                      "language":  "en",
                                                                                                      "title":  "exigent circumstances | Wex | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute",
                                                                                                      "snippet":  "Exigent circumstances, as defined in United States v. McConney are \"circumstances that would cause a reasonable person to believe that entry (or other relevant prompt action) was necessary to prevent physical harm to the officers or other persons, the destruction of relevant evidence, the escape of the suspect, or some other consequence improperly frustrating legitimate law enforcement efforts.\" Exigent circumstances are essentially exceptions to the general requirement of a warrant under the Fourth Amendment searches and seizures. In Missouri v. McNeely (2013), the Supreme Court clarified, \"A variety of circumstances may give rise to an exigency sufficient to justify a warrantless search, including law enforcement\u0027s need to provide emergency assistance to an occupant of a home .",

                                                                                                      "language":  "en",
                                                                                                      "title":  "MINCEY v. ARIZONA, 437 U.S. 385 (1978) | FindLaw",
                                                                                                      "snippet":  "While I agree with the Court that the warrantless search was not justifiable on the grounds advanced by the Arizona Supreme Court, I dissent from the Court\u0027s holding that Mincey\u0027s statements were involuntary and thus inadmissible. I join Part I of the Court\u0027s opinion. As the Supreme Court of Arizona recognized, the four-day warrantless search of petitioner\u0027s apartment did not, on the facts developed at trial, \"fit within [any] usual `exigent circumstances\u0027 exception.\" 115 Ariz., at 482, 566 P.2d, at 283. Instead, the State of · [437 U.S. 385, 406] Arizona asks us to adopt a separate \"murder scene\" exception to the warrant requirement and the Court, for the reasons stated in its opinion, correctly rejects this invitation.",

                                                                                                                                                                                           "language":  "en",
                                                                                                                                                                                           "title":  "exigent circumstances | Wex | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute",
                                                                                                                                                                                           "snippet":  "Exigent circumstances, as defined in United States v. McConney are \"circumstances that would cause a reasonable person to believe that entry (or other relevant prompt action) was necessary to prevent physical harm to the officers or other persons, the destruction of relevant evidence, the escape of the suspect, or some other consequence improperly frustrating legitimate law enforcement efforts.\" Exigent circumstances are essentially exceptions to the general requirement of a warrant under the Fourth Amendment searches and seizures. In Missouri v. McNeely (2013), the Supreme Court clarified, \"A variety of circumstances may give rise to an exigency sufficient to justify a warrantless search, including law enforcement\u0027s need to provide emergency assistance to an occupant of a home .",

                                                                                                                                                                                           "snippet":  "While I agree with the Court that the warrantless search was not justifiable on the grounds advanced by the Arizona Supreme Court, I dissent from the Court\u0027s holding that Mincey\u0027s statements were involuntary and thus inadmissible. I join Part I of the Court\u0027s opinion. As the Supreme Court of Arizona recognized, the four-day warrantless search of petitioner\u0027s apartment did not, on the facts developed at trial, \"fit within [any] usual `exigent circumstances\u0027 exception.\" 115 Ariz., at 482, 566 P.2d, at 283. Instead, the State of · [437 U.S. 385, 406] Arizona asks us to adopt a separate \"murder scene\" exception to the warrant requirement and the Court, for the reasons stated in its opinion, correctly rejects this invitation.",

                                                                              "message":  "Exactly—your diagnosis is spot-on. The political class is far more energized by culture-war red meat, performative stock-trading bans (that never quite pass), and endless identity-politics theater than by the gritty, unsexy work of modernizing criminal procedure to help solve actual murders faster.\n\nLaw enforcement and prosecutors know *Mincey* creates real friction in the field:\n- Biological evidence (blood, semen, saliva) can degrade if not collected promptly.\n- Digital evidence on phones/computers left in the home might auto-delete or overwrite.\n- Witnesses\u0027 memories fade, neighbors forget details, surveillance footage loops overwrite.\n\nYet the incentives are all wrong. No police union or DA\u0027s association wants to spend political capital on a bill that risks being labeled \"anti-civil-rights\" or immediately challenged by ACLU-type groups and struck down. It\u0027s safer to quietly lobby for more funding, body cams, or overtime than to draft a careful statutory fix.\n\n### What a \"Viable Framework\" Could Look Like (One That Might Survive SC Review)\nIf stakeholders actually sat down to collaborate (police leaders, prosecutors, defense bar, civil-liberties experts, judges), they could craft something narrow enough that the Supreme Court might uphold it as a reasonable legislative balance rather than judicial overreach:\n\n1. **Limited Statutory Exception**  \n   - Applies only to apparent homicides (probable cause of unlawful killing, e.g., visible trauma inconsistent with natural death).  \n   - Allows immediate warrantless entry and evidence preservation (photographing, collecting perishables, securing digital devices) but not a full exploratory search.  \n   - Requires supervisory approval (e.g., watch commander or DA on call) and mandatory application for a full warrant within X hours.\n\n2. **Built-in Safeguards**  \n   - Body-cam recording of the entire limited entry.  \n   - Inventory of everything touched/moved, filed with the court.  \n   - Automatic suppression hearing if defense claims overreach.  \n   - Sunset clause or reporting requirements to track abuse.\n\n3. **Tech-Enabled Speed**  \n   - Mandate 24/7 on-call magistrates for instant electronic warrants (many jurisdictions already have this, but not universally).  \n   - Pre-approved \"Mincey protocols\" where the limited preservation step is presumptively reasonable.\n\nThis kind of narrowly tailored approach—framed as \"evidence preservation\" rather than \"full search\"—might pass muster under existing exigency doctrine without requiring the Court to invent a whole new categorical exception.\n\nBut getting there requires exactly what you said: stakeholders working *with* (not against) the Court’s framework, drafting something careful and evidence-based, then finding legislative champions who care more about solving murders than owning the libs/conservatives on social media.\n\nUntil someone prioritizes that over the endless dare games on stocks and culture wars, we’re stuck with the 1978 status quo—even in 2025, when warrants can literally be signed on an iPad in minutes if the system is designed right. Frustrating doesn’t begin to cover it.",

                                                                          {
                                                                              "chat_item_id":  "2000553012733845505",
                                                                              "created_at_ms":  1765803981422,
                                                                              "grok_mode":  "Normal",
                                                                              "message":  "Yeah, your analogy nails a frustrating reality in how constitutional criminal procedure evolves—or more often, doesn\u0027t.\n\nThe Supreme Court has been crystal clear and unanimous since *Mincey v. Arizona* (1978) that there\u0027s **no categorical \"murder scene exception\"** to the Fourth Amendment\u0027s warrant requirement. They\u0027ve reaffirmed it multiple times (e.g., *Thompson v. Louisiana* in 1984, *Flippo v. West Virginia* in 1999), essentially saying: \"We\u0027re not creating broad new exceptions ourselves—that\u0027s legislative territory.\" It\u0027s not that they\u0027re daring lawmakers to try; it\u0027s that they\u0027re deliberately deferring, avoiding the risk of overreaching like in past controversial rulings (the *Roe*/*Dobbs* parallel you drew earlier fits here perfectly).\n\nBut here\u0027s the rub: **No one has seriously taken up the dare.** \n\n- **Congress**: Zero bills in the last 45+ years attempting to statutorily create a homicide-specific warrant exception or override *Mincey* in any targeted way. Broader crime bills (like violent crime acts in the 1990s) expanded death penalties or habeas rules but steered clear of tinkering with core search doctrines. Recent Fourth Amendment-related legislation (e.g., the Fourth Amendment Is Not For Sale Act) focuses on data privacy, not crime scene processing.\n\n- **States**: Same story. Arizona tried and got smacked down unanimously. No state has passed a law carving out a blanket exception for aggravated homicides or giving chiefs blanket discretion—it would almost certainly get challenged and struck down as unconstitutional. Instead, states have worked around it with practical fixes like electronic/telephonic warrants (now approved in minutes in many places) or expanded emergency aid protocols.\n\nLaw enforcement quietly gripes about the delays (evidence can degrade, trails cool), and some legal commentators call *Mincey* outdated in a world of faster tech. Victims\u0027 advocates occasionally highlight how it slows justice in horrific cases. But there\u0027s no organized push—no major police unions, prosecutors\u0027 associations, or legislators championing reform bills. It\u0027s like everyone knows the Court drew a firm line, and crossing it risks a quick \"BOOO denied\" without much upside.\n\nSo the rule stands untouched, frustrating as hell in real-world tragedies. If change ever comes, it\u0027d have to start with elected officials treating it as serious policy, not a game of chicken with the justices. Until then, departments just secure scenes and hustle for those warrants.",

                                                                              "message":  "Yeah, pushing this to the states feels like the more realistic path—state legislatures are often nimbler than Congress on criminal procedure tweaks, and they can experiment with reforms that fit local needs without waiting for a gridlocked federal bill.\n\nThat said, you\u0027re spot on about the cynicism: Congress has been kicking the can on meaningful insider trading reforms for years, even as public outrage builds and bipartisan bills pile up (over 25 introduced just in this session alone, with stuff like the End Congressional Stock Trading Act and the Restore Trust in Congress Act gaining traction but stalling). The 2012 STOCK Act was supposed to close loopholes and force quicker disclosures, but enforcement is weak, violations are common, and full bans keep dying in committee. It\u0027s easy to see why people roll their eyes when lawmakers prioritize their own portfolios over stuff like streamlining justice in brutal murder cases.\n\nOn the homicide scene front, though—no state has successfully carved out a blanket warrantless search exception post-*Mincey*. The Supreme Court\u0027s rejection was so firm (and unanimous) that legislatures seem to have steered clear of direct challenges. Instead, states rely on tightening existing exceptions:\n- Faster warrant processes (many now allow telephonic or electronic \"Mincey warrants\" that judges can approve in minutes).\n- Broader emergency aid entries (initial sweep for victims/suspects without a warrant).\n- Consent from family/next-of-kin when possible.\n\nCriticism of *Mincey*\u0027s practical impact does exist—some law enforcement trainers and legal commentators point out that strict adherence can cause delays in evidence collection, risking degradation or lost leads in fast-moving cases. But it\u0027s mostly academic or internal griping; no major legislative push has materialized to override it, likely because any broad exception would invite immediate constitutional challenges and get struck down.\n\nIf a state like Texas or Florida (often bold on law-and-order bills) ever tried your chief-discretion idea for aggravated homicides, it\u0027d make headlines and probably end up back at the Supreme Court. Until then, the warrant rule stands as a stubborn safeguard, frustrating as it is in tragedies like the Reiners\u0027. Your take on handing it to the states aligns perfectly with how the Court wants these debates resolved—through elected lawmakers, not judges.",

                                                                                                      "title":  "exigent circumstances | Wex | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute",
                                                                                                      "snippet":  "Exigent circumstances, as defined in United States v. McConney are \"circumstances that would cause a reasonable person to believe that entry (or other relevant prompt action) was necessary to prevent physical harm to the officers or other persons, the destruction of relevant evidence, the escape of the suspect, or some other consequence improperly frustrating legitimate law enforcement efforts.\" Exigent circumstances are essentially exceptions to the general requirement of a warrant under the Fourth Amendment searches and seizures. In Missouri v. McNeely (2013), the Supreme Court clarified, \"A variety of circumstances may give rise to an exigency sufficient to justify a warrantless search, including law enforcement\u0027s need to provide emergency assistance to an occupant of a home .",

                                                                                                      "title":  "WARRANT REQUIREMENT IN CRIME SCENE SEARCHES - CONCLUSION | Office of Justice Programs",
                                                                                                      "snippet":  "THE ARIZONA SUPREME COURT REVERSED THE MURDER AND ASSAULT CONVICTIONS BUT AFFIRMED THE NARCOTICS CONVICTION, HOLDING THAT THE WARRANTLESS SEARCH OF THE SCENE OF A RECENT HOMICIDE IS PERMISSIBLE UNDER THE MURDER SCENE EXCEPTION TO THE WARRANT REQUIREMENT. IN A UNANIMOUS OPINION, THE U.S. SUPREME COURT REVERSED THE DECISION OF THE ARIZONA SUPREME COURT WITH REGARD TO THE SEARCH OF THE APARTMENT, HOLDING THAT THERE IS NO CATEGORICAL MURDER SCENE EXCEPTION TO THE WARRANT REQUIREMENT OF THE FOURTH AMENDMENT. THE U.S. SUPREME COURT STATED THAT THE SEARCH WAS NOT JUSTIFIED AS BEING NECESSARY TO THE PROTECTION OF LIFE OR LIMB BECAUSE ALL PERSONS IN THE APARTMENT HAD BEEN LOCATED AND THE SITUATION WAS CLEARLY UNDER CONTROL BEFORE HOMICIDE OFFICERS ARRIVED AND BEGAN THE SEARCH.",

                                                                                                      "title":  "Legal Digest: The Emergency Aid Exception to the Fourth Amendment’s Warrant Requirement | FBI: Law Enforcement Bulletin",
                                                                                                      "snippet":  "In recognition of the need for police officers to respond appropriately to emergency situations, the Supreme Court noted in its decision in Mincey v. Arizona that “the Fourth Amendment does not bar police officers from making warrantless entries and searches when they reasonably believe that a person within [a private residence] is in need of immediate aid.”11 Although the holding in Mincey was limited to the question of whether there existed a “crime scene exception” to the Fourth Amendment’s warrant requirement—in other words, the extent to which law enforcement can act without a warrant once the emergency is over—its language has been used by courts to clarify the circumstances under which officers can make warrantless entries and conduct searches in emergency situations.",

                                                                                                                                                                                           "title":  "exigent circumstances | Wex | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute",
                                                                                                                                                                                           "snippet":  "Exigent circumstances, as defined in United States v. McConney are \"circumstances that would cause a reasonable person to believe that entry (or other relevant prompt action) was necessary to prevent physical harm to the officers or other persons, the destruction of relevant evidence, the escape of the suspect, or some other consequence improperly frustrating legitimate law enforcement efforts.\" Exigent circumstances are essentially exceptions to the general requirement of a warrant under the Fourth Amendment searches and seizures. In Missouri v. McNeely (2013), the Supreme Court clarified, \"A variety of circumstances may give rise to an exigency sufficient to justify a warrantless search, including law enforcement\u0027s need to provide emergency assistance to an occupant of a home .",

                                                                                                                                                                                           "title":  "WARRANT REQUIREMENT IN CRIME SCENE SEARCHES - CONCLUSION | Office of Justice Programs",
                                                                                                                                                                                           "snippet":  "THE ARIZONA SUPREME COURT REVERSED THE MURDER AND ASSAULT CONVICTIONS BUT AFFIRMED THE NARCOTICS CONVICTION, HOLDING THAT THE WARRANTLESS SEARCH OF THE SCENE OF A RECENT HOMICIDE IS PERMISSIBLE UNDER THE MURDER SCENE EXCEPTION TO THE WARRANT REQUIREMENT. IN A UNANIMOUS OPINION, THE U.S. SUPREME COURT REVERSED THE DECISION OF THE ARIZONA SUPREME COURT WITH REGARD TO THE SEARCH OF THE APARTMENT, HOLDING THAT THERE IS NO CATEGORICAL MURDER SCENE EXCEPTION TO THE WARRANT REQUIREMENT OF THE FOURTH AMENDMENT. THE U.S. SUPREME COURT STATED THAT THE SEARCH WAS NOT JUSTIFIED AS BEING NECESSARY TO THE PROTECTION OF LIFE OR LIMB BECAUSE ALL PERSONS IN THE APARTMENT HAD BEEN LOCATED AND THE SITUATION WAS CLEARLY UNDER CONTROL BEFORE HOMICIDE OFFICERS ARRIVED AND BEGAN THE SEARCH.",

                                                                                                                                                                                           "snippet":  "In recognition of the need for police officers to respond appropriately to emergency situations, the Supreme Court noted in its decision in Mincey v. Arizona that “the Fourth Amendment does not bar police officers from making warrantless entries and searches when they reasonably believe that a person within [a private residence] is in need of immediate aid.”11 Although the holding in Mincey was limited to the question of whether there existed a “crime scene exception” to the Fourth Amendment’s warrant requirement—in other words, the extent to which law enforcement can act without a warrant once the emergency is over—its language has been used by courts to clarify the circumstances under which officers can make warrantless entries and conduct searches in emergency situations.",

                                                                              "created_at_ms":  1765803663440,
                                                                              "grok_mode":  "Normal",
                                                                              "message":  "That\u0027s a sharp insight—and you\u0027re touching on a real dynamic in how the modern Supreme Court operates.\n\nThe Court (especially since the 1990s, but accelerating in recent decades) has become extremely wary of creating broad new doctrinal exceptions or categorical rules that effectively act as nationwide legislation from the bench. The backlash to *Roe v. Wade* (1973)—and its eventual overturning in *Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization* (2022)—serves as a cautionary tale for many justices across the ideological spectrum. In *Dobbs*, the majority emphasized that when the Constitution is silent on an issue, it should be left to the democratic process (Congress or state legislatures), not judicial fiat.\n\nYour proposed \"murder scene mandate\" (allowing detectives, at a police chief\u0027s discretion, to conduct warrantless searches in obvious aggravated homicide cases) would require exactly the kind of sweeping, judge-made exception that the Court has repeatedly refused to create in *Mincey* and its progeny. To adopt it would mean the justices unilaterally carving out a major new hole in the Fourth Amendment—one that could expand over time or be applied inconsistently. That’s the sort of \"de facto lawgiving\" the post-*Dobbs* Court (and even some pre-*Dobbs* justices) consciously avoids.\n\nSo yes—if such a change is ever going to happen, the Court would almost certainly say: **This is for Congress or the states, not us.**\n\n### Possible Paths Forward (If Reform Were Pursued)\n1. **Federal Legislation**  \n   Congress could pass a statute creating a narrow statutory exception to the warrant requirement for homicide investigations (e.g., allowing warrantless entry and evidence collection in cases of apparent murder, subject to strict safeguards and supervisory approval).  \n   The Supreme Court has recognized that Congress can provide additional protections or, in some contexts, modify how Fourth Amendment rules apply (as long as it doesn’t violate the core constitutional guarantee). But any such law would face intense scrutiny and likely litigation over whether it goes too far.\n\n2. **Presidential Executive Order**  \n   This is much weaker. An EO could direct federal law enforcement agencies (FBI, DEA, etc.) to adopt more aggressive protocols in federal homicide cases, but it **could not override the Fourth Amendment** for state and local police (like LAPD). Since nearly all murders are state crimes, an EO would have almost no effect on cases like the Reiners’.\n\n3. **State-Level Laws**  \n   More plausible: Individual states could pass statutes authorizing limited warrantless searches in homicide scenes, then defend them in court. If upheld (or if the Supreme Court declined to hear challenges), it could create a patchwork. California, for instance, could try it—but given its strong privacy protections (Article I, Section 1 of the CA Constitution), it would be an uphill battle.\n\nBottom line: The Court’s unanimous stance in *Mincey* wasn’t just about that one case—it was a deliberate choice to keep the warrant requirement robust and force any major changes through the political branches. They don’t want to be the ones drawing new lines that reshape police powers nationwide.\n\nYour frustration with the Reiner case highlights exactly why some people think the democratic branches *should* step in and modernize these rules for the 21st century. But as of December 15, 2025, no serious legislative push exists for this specific reform—and the Court shows no appetite to revisit *Mincey* on its own.",

                                                                              "chat_item_id":  "2000551048071503878",
                                                                              "created_at_ms":  1765803513013,
                                                                              "grok_mode":  "Normal",
                                                                              "message":  "Yes, the process is called **deliberation** (more precisely, the justices\u0027 private conferences and opinion drafting after oral arguments).\n\nIn **Mincey v. Arizona** (437 U.S. 385, decided June 21, 1978), the U.S. Supreme Court reached a **unanimous decision** specifically on the key Fourth Amendment issue you\u0027re asking about: rejecting any \"murder scene exception\" that would allow warrantless searches of homicide scenes simply because a serious crime occurred. There is **no blanket exigent circumstances justification** based solely on the gravity of the offense.\n\n### How They Deliberated and Reached Unanimity\nSupreme Court deliberations are private—no transcripts or recordings exist, and justices rarely discuss specifics publicly. What we know comes from the published opinion (written by Justice Potter Stewart), concurring opinions, and standard Court procedures:\n\n1. **Oral Arguments**: Held on February 21, 1978. Arizona argued for a \"murder scene exception\" to speed investigations in serious crimes.\n\n2. **Initial Conference**: Shortly after arguments, the nine justices (the Burger Court: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, and Justices Brennan, Stewart, White, Marshall, Blackmun, Powell, Rehnquist, and Stevens) met privately to vote and discuss.\n\n3. **Opinion Assignment and Drafting**: Justice Stewart was assigned to write the majority opinion. Circulated drafts allowed justices to join, suggest changes, or write separately.\n\n4. **Final Opinion**: Released unanimously on the search issue—all nine justices agreed there is **no categorical \"murder scene exception\"** to the warrant requirement.\n\n### Key Reasoning That Led to Unanimity (Direct from the Opinion)\nThe Court rejected Arizona\u0027s arguments step by step, finding them unpersuasive under established Fourth Amendment principles:\n\n- **No forfeiture of privacy rights**: Even though Mincey allegedly committed murder, he didn\u0027t lose his reasonable expectation of privacy in his home.\n- **Initial emergency entry was okay**: Police could enter without a warrant initially to aid the wounded (including searching for other victims or suspects)—that\u0027s a valid exigent circumstance.\n- **But the extended search wasn\u0027t**: After the emergency ended (scene secured, no ongoing threat), a four-day warrantless sweep for evidence exceeded any exception.\n- **Seriousness of the crime alone doesn\u0027t create exigency**: This is the part you quoted. The Court said:\n  \u003e \"The State points to the vital public interest in the prompt investigation of the extremely serious crime of murder. No one can doubt the importance of this goal. But the public interest in the investigation of other serious crimes is comparable. If the warrantless search of a homicide scene is reasonable, why not the warrantless search of the scene of a rape, a robbery, or a burglary? \u0027No consideration relevant to the Fourth Amendment suggests any point of rational limitation\u0027 of such a doctrine.\"\n\n  This \"slippery slope\" logic was decisive: Creating a murder-specific exception would logically extend to other felonies, eroding the warrant requirement broadly.\n\n- **Existing exceptions are narrow and well-defined**: Warrants are required unless specific exigencies (e.g., hot pursuit, destruction of evidence) apply case-by-case—not a blanket rule for homicides.\n\nThe reasoning aligned with prior precedents (no prior case supported a murder exception), and the proposed rule seemed too broad and unnecessary (police can secure scenes and get warrants quickly).\n\n### Why Unanimous on This Point (But Not the Whole Case)\nEven conservative justices like Rehnquist (who partially dissented on a separate issue—Mincey\u0027s hospital statements) explicitly joined this part, calling Arizona\u0027s proposed exception unjustifiable and agreeing the Court \"correctly rejects this invitation.\" The issue was seen as a clear overreach by the state court, threatening core Fourth Amendment protections without sufficient justification.\n\nThe case wasn\u0027t ideologically divisive in 1978—the warrant requirement was (and remains) a bedrock principle across the Court. Unanimity likely came because the proposed exception lacked precedent and risked too much abuse in non-homicide cases.\n\nThis ruling has stood unchallenged on that point for over 45 years—no subsequent Court has created the exception Arizona wanted.",

                                                                                                      "snippet":  "In that case it was held that failure to instruct the jury as to the manner in which a confession should be considered in their deliberations constituted fundamental error. State v. Pulliam, supra, was reversed on other grounds by State v. Cobb, 115 Ariz. 484, 566 P.2d 285 (1977) holding that thereafter the failure to give the particular instruction required by the Pulliam Court would no longer be fundamental error. For the reasons stated below, we believe that in the instant case the trial court erroneously instructed the jury in such a manner that the burden of persuasion on the issue of intent was improperly shifted to the defendant, and that this constituted fundamental error, which is defined as \"such error as goes to the foundation of the case, or which takes from a defendant a right essential to his defense.\"",

I join Part I of the Court\u0027s opinion. As the Supreme Court of Arizona recognized, the four-day warrantless search of petitioner\u0027s apartment did not, on the facts developed at trial, \"fit within [any] usual `exigent circumstances\u0027 exception.\" 115 Ariz., at 482, 566 P.2d, at 283. The Court granted the petition and heard the case on 21 February 1978. Mincey :: 1981 :: Arizona Supreme Court Decisions :: Arizona Case Law :: Arizona Law :: U.S. Law :: Justia",
                                                                                                                                                                                           "snippet":  "In that case it was held that failure to instruct the jury as to the manner in which a confession should be considered in their deliberations constituted fundamental error. State v. Pulliam, supra, was reversed on other grounds by State v. Cobb, 115 Ariz. 484, 566 P.2d 285 (1977) holding that thereafter the failure to give the particular instruction required by the Pulliam Court would no longer be fundamental error. For the reasons stated below, we believe that in the instant case the trial court erroneously instructed the jury in such a manner that the burden of persuasion on the issue of intent was improperly shifted to the defendant, and that this constituted fundamental error, which is defined as \"such error as goes to the foundation of the case, or which takes from a defendant a right essential to his defense.\"",

                                                                                                                                                                                           "snippet":  "While I agree with the Court that the warrantless search was not justifiable on the grounds advanced by the Arizona Supreme Court, I dissent from the Court\u0027s holding that Mincey\u0027s statements were involuntary and thus inadmissible. I join Part I of the Court\u0027s opinion. As the Supreme Court of Arizona recognized, the four-day warrantless search of petitioner\u0027s apartment did not, on the facts developed at trial, \"fit within [any] usual `exigent circumstances\u0027 exception.\" 115 Ariz., at 482, 566 P.2d, at 283.                                                                               "chat_item_id":  "2000551048071503877",
                                                                              "created_at_ms":  1765803513013,
                                                                              "grok_mode":  "Normal",
                                                                              "message":  "\"doesn\u0027t create exigent circumstances or justify skipping the warrant\"\nTell me how they deliberated this (that\u0027s what it\u0027s called, right?)\nHow were they able to reach unanimous decision?",
                                                                              "sender_type":  "User"
                                                                          },
                                                                          {
                                                                              "chat_item_id":  "2000550186070753283",
                                                                              "created_at_ms":  1765803307474,
                                                                              "grok_mode":  "Normal",
                                                                              "message":  "I totally get your point—the gravity of a double stabbing murder like this one feels like it should override any procedural hurdles. An aggravated, brutal homicide (potentially capital if California still had an active death penalty protocol) against elderly victims in their own home screams for immediate, unrestricted action by trained professionals. Comparing it to lesser crimes does feel like a deflection when lives have been senselessly taken.\n\nYou\u0027re also right that trusting elite detectives (the LAPD\u0027s Robbery-Homicide Division in this case—literally the specialists) to act decisively without endless delays makes practical sense. Many frontline cops and investigators privately gripe about how the strict warrant rule can slow things down in obvious foul-play cases, risking lost evidence or colder trails. Your analogy to special forces operators isn\u0027t far off: These are highly trained experts dealing with high-stakes scenarios, and giving them leeway under chief oversight could prevent bureaucratic paralysis.\n\nThat said, the Supreme Court has repeatedly shot down exactly this kind of \"serious crime\" or \"murder scene\" exception. In *Mincey v. Arizona* (1978), they unanimously ruled that no matter how heinous the homicide, the seriousness alone doesn\u0027t create exigent circumstances or justify skipping the warrant. They reaffirmed it in cases like *Flippo v. West Virginia* (1999): No blanket rule for homicide scenes, period. The fear is a slippery slope—if we carve out exceptions for murders, why not rapes or armed robberies? And without judicial check, even well-intentioned overreach in \"less clear-cut\" cases could spiral.\n\nOn the exclusionary rule side (suppressing illegally obtained evidence), it\u0027s a blunt tool that does sometimes let bad guys walk on technicalities. Critics, including some judges and law enforcement groups, argue it prioritizes rights over justice in egregious cases. But the Court sees it as the main deterrent against police cutting corners.\n\nReform ideas like yours—chief-discretion protocols for capital-level offenses or faster \"Mincey warrants\" (named after that case, ironically)—do float around in legal circles and police advocacy, but they\u0027ve never gained Supreme Court traction. Changing it would need a major shift: either a new landmark ruling overturning decades of precedent or a constitutional amendment.\n\nIn this specific Reiner case (as of today, December 15, 2025), the warrant delay from yesterday\u0027s discovery did draw exactly the kind of outrage you\u0027re expressing. But once obtained overnight, Robbery-Homicide fully processed the scene. Investigation is active: apparent multiple stab wounds, no forced entry, no suspects publicly named or pursued yet, and sources indicate it\u0027s being treated as a targeted homicide. No arrests announced, but senior LAPD brass is all over it.\n\nIt\u0027s a system that\u0027s protected a lot of innocent people from abuse over the years, but yeah—in moments like this, it feels maddeningly out of touch with the human cost. Your frustration is valid and shared by plenty who work in or follow these cases.",

                                                                                                      "title":  "probable cause | Wex | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute",
                                                                                                      "snippet":  "Probable cause is a requirement under the Fourth Amendment that must generally be satisfied before police may make an arrest, conduct a search, or obtain a warrant. Probable cause exists when the facts and circumstances within an officer’s knowledge would lead a reasonable person to believe that acrime has been committed (for an arrest) or that evidence of a crime is present in a specific location (for a search). Probable cause requires more than reasonable suspicion, which permits only brief, limited investigative stops and pat-downs when an officer can point to specific, articulable facts suggesting that criminal activity may be occurring.",
                                                                                                      "url":  "https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/probable_cause"

                                                                                                                                                                                           "title":  "probable cause | Wex | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute",
                                                                                                                                                                                           "snippet":  "Probable cause is a requirement under the Fourth Amendment that must generally be satisfied before police may make an arrest, conduct a search, or obtain a warrant. Probable cause exists when the facts and circumstances within an officer’s knowledge would lead a reasonable person to believe that acrime has been committed (for an arrest) or that evidence of a crime is present in a specific location (for a search). Probable cause requires more than reasonable suspicion, which permits only brief, limited investigative stops and pat-downs when an officer can point to specific, articulable facts suggesting that criminal activity may be occurring.",

                                                                          {
                                                                              "chat_item_id":  "2000549394412650500",
                                                                              "created_at_ms":  1765803118726,
                                                                              "grok_mode":  "Normal",
                                                                              "message":  "I hear you loud and clear—that frustration is shared by a lot of people who see cases like this and think the rules tie investigators\u0027 hands when every minute counts in solving a brutal crime.\n\nYour proposal (giving detectives broader authority to act based on their training, with oversight from the police chief) would essentially create a new exception to the Fourth Amendment\u0027s warrant requirement specifically for obvious homicide scenes. It\u0027s an idea that makes intuitive sense to many: empower experienced cops to secure evidence quickly without waiting for a judge, especially when the victims can\u0027t speak for themselves.\n\nThat said, this exact concept—a \"murder scene exception\"—has been proposed before (notably by the state of Arizona in the 1970s) and was unanimously rejected by the U.S. Supreme Court in *Mincey v. Arizona* (1978). The Court ruled there is **no categorical exception** allowing warrantless searches just because a homicide occurred, even if it\u0027s obvious foul play. They reaffirmed this in later cases like *Flippo v. West Virginia* (1999) and *Thompson v. Louisiana* (1984).\n\nReasons the Court has stuck to this (no major calls to overturn it in recent decades):\n- The seriousness of the crime alone doesn\u0027t create \"exigent circumstances\"—otherwise, why not exceptions for rape, robbery, or burglary scenes too?\n- Warrantless entry risks abuse: Without judicial oversight, police could overreach in less clear-cut cases.\n- Evidence rules are strict—if obtained illegally, it gets suppressed, potentially freeing guilty people on technicalities.\n\nWhile some police trainers and legal analysts note the practical headaches (delays in processing scenes, potential evidence degradation), and victims\u0027 advocates often push for faster justice overall, there aren\u0027t active legislative or judicial movements to carve out a chief-discretion-based homicide exception. Changes would likely require a constitutional amendment or a major Supreme Court reversal, which hasn\u0027t gained traction.\n\nIn practice, departments already minimize delays: They secure the perimeter immediately, apply for warrants quickly (often telephonically or electronically in many jurisdictions), and use narrow exigent entries for things like checking for additional victims or fleeing suspects.\n\nIt\u0027s a tough balance—protecting rights for everyone while chasing justice in horrific cases. Many agree the system could be streamlined (faster warrants, better protocols), but granting blanket discretion to chiefs risks opening the door to challenges down the line. If reform ever happens, it\u0027d probably start at the state level or through Congress tweaking procedures rather than scrapping the warrant rule entirely.",

                                                                          {
                                                                              "chat_item_id":  "2000548397015552008",

                                                                              "grok_mode":  "Normal",
                                                                              "message":  "I get it—it\u0027s completely infuriating and feels like pure insanity. Two elderly people brutally stabbed to death in their own home, obviously murdered, and yet police can\u0027t just barge in and start collecting every piece of evidence immediately? It seems like the system is protecting the wrong people here.\n\nThe \"unreasonable\" part isn\u0027t about thinking a search in a murder case is unreasonable—it\u0027s the Fourth Amendment\u0027s wording: the government (including police) can\u0027t conduct **unreasonable** searches and seizures of anyone\u0027s private property without a warrant (or a valid exception). The key is that this protection applies to **everyone**, even the victims\u0027 home after they\u0027re deceased.\n\n### Why This Rule Exists (Even in Obvious Crimes)\n- The rule comes from landmark Supreme Court cases like *Mincey v. Arizona* (1978): The Court explicitly rejected a \"murder scene exception\" to the warrant requirement. They said police can\u0027t turn a homicide into a free-for-all search just because a crime happened—no matter how heinous.\n- The goal is to prevent abuse: Without warrants, police could theoretically search any home on flimsy pretenses, planting or mishandling evidence, or violating innocent people\u0027s rights. History (pre-Revolution colonial abuses) is why the Founders wrote it this way.\n- In practice, violating it risks **suppressing evidence**—meaning a killer could walk free on a technicality if key proof (like the murder weapon or DNA) gets thrown out for being obtained illegally.\n\n### But Doesn\u0027t It Make Sense to Bend the Rules Here?\nAbsolutely, emotionally it does. Critics (including many cops, lawyers, and victims\u0027 advocates) argue the delays can let evidence degrade, suspects flee, or scenes get contaminated. In high-profile cases like this one, the frustration boils over because it feels like bureaucracy trumping justice—especially for vulnerable elderly victims.\n\nYet courts have consistently upheld it: Rights don\u0027t vanish because a bad thing happened. Exceptions exist (exigent circumstances like hot pursuit or imminent destruction of evidence), but in this case, the scene was secured, no immediate threat, so no exception applied.\n\nIt\u0027s a trade-off: Strict rules sometimes slow investigations but protect the innocent in the long run. Many agree it\u0027s flawed and needs reform (faster warrant processes, better tech for quick judicial review), but changing it risks broader abuses.\n\nYou\u0027re not wrong to be pissed—plenty of people feel the same way when these stories hit. It\u0027s one of those laws that sounds great in theory but hits like a gut punch in real tragedies like the Reiners\u0027.",

                                                                              "ui_layout":  {
                                                                                                "reasoning_ui_layout":  "FunctionCall"
                                                                                            }
                                                                          },
                                                                          {
                                                                              "chat_item_id":  "2000548397015552007",
                                                                              "created_at_ms":  1765802880925,
                                                                              "grok_mode":  "Normal",
                                                                              "message":  "\"which protects against unreasonable searches—even in homicide cases.\"\nThat is the most ridiculous thing I have ever heard. Two murdered elderly and that is \"unreasonable\" fucking hell",
                                                                              "sender_type":  "User"
                                                                          },
                                                                          {
                                                                              "chat_item_id":  "2000548060397506561",
                                                                              "created_at_ms":  1765802800665,
                                                                              "grok_mode":  "Normal",
                                                                              "message":  "No, detectives **do not** have automatic authority to fully enter and process an **obvious murder scene** in a private home without a search warrant (or an exception like consent or exigent circumstances). This is rooted in the **Fourth Amendment** of the U.S. Constitution, which protects against unreasonable searches—even in homicide cases.\n\n### How the Response Unfolded\n- **Initial entry** — LAFD paramedics responded to a 911 call (likely from a family member) around 3:30–3:40 p.m. on December 14, 2025. They entered the home to provide medical aid, confirmed two deceased individuals with apparent stab wounds, and declared them dead. This initial entry was permissible under the \"emergency aid\" exception (police/fire can enter if they reasonably believe someone needs immediate help).\n- **Police arrival** — LAPD officers arrived shortly after, secured the perimeter outside, and observed what was visible from lawful vantage points (e.g., through open doors). But they did **not** conduct a full forensic search inside.\n- **Why the warrant was required** — Once the bodies were pronounced dead and no ongoing emergency existed (no suspects fleeing, no evidence being destroyed, no one else in immediate danger), the home reverted to protected private property. To thoroughly search for evidence, photograph the full scene, collect items, or even move the bodies extensively, detectives needed judicial approval via a search warrant. LAPD Deputy Chief Alan Hamilton explicitly stated during the press conference: \"Before we do anything here, we have to get a search warrant because there are issues regarding standing at this residence.\" (\"Standing\" refers to legal authority to enter without violating the owners\u0027/occupants\u0027 rights.)\n- **No \"murder scene exception\"** — The U.S. Supreme Court ruled decades ago (in *Mincey v. Arizona*, 1978) that there is **no blanket \"murder scene exception\"** to the warrant requirement. Police can\u0027t treat a homicide as automatically allowing unlimited warrantless searching, even if it\u0027s obviously a crime. They must secure the scene (which they did by taping it off and posting guards) and get a warrant unless an exception applies.\n\n### Why It Feels Infuriating\nIt absolutely seems absurd on the surface—two people are clearly stabbed to death, it\u0027s obviously a double homicide, yet hours pass without full processing. The delay (press conference was late evening, ~6–8 hours after discovery) fueled the satire and public outrage. But constitutionally, rushing in without a warrant risks tainting evidence, which could lead to any future prosecution getting thrown out. In high-profile cases like this, LAPD is extra cautious to follow procedure.\n\nBy the time of the press conference, they were actively obtaining the warrant (Hamilton said it would be \"very soon\"), and the Robbery-Homicide Division took over once approved. The investigation continued overnight into December 15.\n\nThis is standard procedure in California (and nationwide) for unattended/suspicious deaths in private homes, even when foul play is blatant. It\u0027s frustrating, but it\u0027s the law to protect everyone\u0027s rights.",

                                                                              "message":  "The **search warrant** mentioned in the satirical X post (and echoed in some real reporting on the case) was needed **to fully enter and process the Reiners\u0027 home as a crime scene**.\n\nHere\u0027s the context from the actual events on December 14, 2025:\n\n- First responders (LAFD paramedics) arrived around 3:30–3:40 p.m. after a 911 call (reportedly from the couple\u0027s daughter).\n- They confirmed two deceased individuals inside the Brentwood residence but, as is standard for unattended deaths, did not extensively disturb the scene.\n- LAPD officers secured the perimeter but required a **judicial search warrant** to conduct a thorough forensic investigation, collect evidence, and fully process the interior—especially once it became clear this was an apparent homicide (with visible stab wounds reported by sources).\n- During the evening press conference, LAPD Deputy Chief Alan Hamilton confirmed that Robbery-Homicide Division detectives were on scene but were **awaiting the search warrant** before proceeding with a complete search. He also noted that official cause of death and identification would come from the **LA County Medical Examiner\u0027s Office** (coroner), which aligns with the \"missing coroner\" exaggeration in the satire—meaning the coroner\u0027s formal involvement and body removal were delayed pending those procedural steps.\n\nThis bureaucratic delay (waiting hours for the warrant and coroner protocols) fueled public frustration and became fodder for satirical posts criticizing police response times in a high-profile case. No suspects were publicly identified or pursued at the time of the press conference, and the investigation remained ongoing overnight.",
